arm_group.description: Ocular light exposure of a red wavelength light
Ocular light exposure of a blue-green wavelength light

brief_summary.textblock:
Specific Aim: Test the hypothesis that ocular light exposure will suppress melatonin
      secretion and reduce uterine contractions in women at late term pregnancies.

      Secondary aim. Test the hypothesis that ocular light exposure will reduce self-reported
      uterine contractions in women at late term pregnancies.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effects of Light on Melatonin and Contractions in Pregnant Women

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  pregnant at 35-40 weeks

          -  first pregnancy

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  pregnancy-related complications

          -  twin or higher pregnancy

          -  using medication that affects the sympathetic nervous system

intervention.description: Ocular light exposure to a red wavelength light
Ocular light exposure to a blue/green wavelength light

clinical_study.official_title: Effects of Light on Melatonin and Contractions in Pregnant Women

other_outcome.description: Self-reported uterine contractions will be assessed by asking the women how many contractions they felt.
other_outcome.measure: Subjective assessment of uterine contractions during experimental light exposure compared with non-light exposure times

primary_outcome.description: Melatonin will be assessed using concentrations in saliva or blood
primary_outcome.measure: Melatonin concentration in saliva and blood during experimental light exposure compared with non-light exposure times

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Uterine contractions will be measured using a uterine tocometer device
secondary_outcome.measure: Uterine contractions during experimental light exposure compared with non-light exposure times

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Basic Science
